sentence: trim front of read for 50 bp; Hi, . I need to trim ONT reads for 50 bp from the start of each read. . When i enter -f 50 option, i get following error back: . ```. ERROR: trim_front1 (--trim_front1) should be 0 ~ 30, suggest 0 ~ 4 . ```. why is there a size limit to front trimming in fastp? . Can it be removed? . If you could point me to the relevant line in code, i can do it myself. . Thanks and best regards, . Michel.

ERROR: trim_front1 (--trim_front1) should be 0 ~ 30, suggest 0 ~ 4 . ```. why is there a size limit to front trimming in fastp? . Can it be removed? . If you could point me to the relevant line in code, i can do it myself. . Thanks and best regards, . Michel.
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: --cut_by_quality3/5 description is confusing; We've been investigating how the --cut_by_quality trimming actually works. Two other issues (#24 and #65) had the same questions we have, and your answers to those were not detailed enough and neither is the description in the documentation. I'll try to spell out my confusion clearly... The --cut_by_quality documentation references Trimmomatic and "sliding window" but it does not work the same way Trimmomatic's SLIDINGWINDOW option works, which is where I think a lot of the confusion comes from. Instead, --cut_by_quality works more similar to Trimmomatic's LEADING and TRAILING options, except it uses a minimum window size of 2 instead of single bases like L/T. Both --cut_by_quality and L/T stop when reaching a window or base above the quality threshold. However, SLIDINGWINDOW slides down the entire sequence and can find low-quality windows in the middle of otherwise high-quality sequence and will discard the rest of the sequence starting at the low-quality window. This is why SLIDINGWINDOW should only be used after LEADING trimming, else the entire sequence that starts with a few low-quality bases would be lost. At the very least, would you please change the documentation for --cut_by_quality to specifically state that it works similar to Trimmomatic's LEADING and TRAILING trimming, not SLIDINGWINDOW? I would also like to request that the minimum window size be allowed to be 1 so we could use it as a single base trimmer. Finally, a further enhancement would be to include an option that does work like SLIDINGWINDOW. Thanks for an otherwise great software tool - we are really pleased with our testing overall and are close to switching to fastp for our production work!
author: OpenGene

However, SLIDINGWINDOW slides down the entire sequence and can find low-quality windows in the middle of otherwise high-quality sequence and will discard the rest of the sequence starting at the low-quality window. This is why SLIDINGWINDOW should only be used after LEADING trimming, else the entire sequence that starts with a few low-quality bases would be lost. At the very least, would you please change the documentation for --cut_by_quality to specifically state that it works similar to Trimmomatic's LEADING and TRAILING trimming, not SLIDINGWINDOW? I would also like to request that the minimum window size be allowed to be 1 so we could use it as a single base trimmer. Finally, a further enhancement would be to include an option that does work like SLIDINGWINDOW. Thanks for an otherwise great software tool - we are really pleased with our testing overall and are close to switching to fastp for our production work!
author: OpenGene

sentence: In the process of Overrepresented sequence analysis, the list of sequences with relatively high occurrence frequency in different sizes is not accurate.; The step 1 in the process of Overrepresented sequence analysis, you use a map to store kmers and iterate map to remove substrings(kmers). But it is sorted by lexicographic order, not by the length of kmer. So in my opioion the result is not accurate.
author: OpenGene

sentence: In the process of Overrepresented sequence analysis, the list of sequences with relatively high occurrence frequency in different sizes is not accurate.; The step 1 in the process of Overrepresented sequence analysis, you use a map to store kmers and iterate map to remove substrings(kmers). But it is sorted by lexicographic order, not by the length of kmer. So in my opioion the result is not accurate.
author: OpenGene

sentence: qualified quality filtering sometimes discards one read in pair; I'm trying to use fastp to only do qualified quality filtering (disabling all other default filtering). My commandline looks like this: . fastp_0.19.4/fastp -i R1.fastq.gz -I R2.fastq.gz -o R1_fp40.fastq.gz -O R2_fp40.fastq.gz -A -G -L -u 40. My aligner sometimes complains that there's a read name mis-match between read1 and read2 which I suspect means that either the fastq sort order has changed or that one read has been filtered but not the other. I can confirm that the aligner does not complain on the original data, only the fastp filtered data of the above command. Thank you for your help and for this brilliant software!
author: OpenGene

My commandline looks like this: . fastp_0.19.4/fastp -i R1.fastq.gz -I R2.fastq.gz -o R1_fp40.fastq.gz -O R2_fp40.fastq.gz -A -G -L -u 40. My aligner sometimes complains that there's a read name mis-match between read1 and read2 which I suspect means that either the fastq sort order has changed or that one read has been filtered but not the other. I can confirm that the aligner does not complain on the original data, only the fastp filtered data of the above command. Thank you for your help and for this brilliant software!
author: OpenGene

sentence: Small typo "defaut"; ```. --stdout stream passing-filters reads to STDOUT. This option will result in interleaved FASTQ output for paired-end input. Disabled by defaut. ```. `defaut` => `default`.

sentence: GC content filter; It would be nice if there were a filter based on the read GC-content as suggested in #76. This filter could be used in addition to the low complexity filter. While the complexity defined in the existing filter for pure GC reads, e.g., `GCGCGCGCGCGC` is 100%, since there are no same bases next to each other, the reads are insufficiently "complex" to align uniquely. I imagin a way to define GC content could be the percentage of neighboring pairs `base[i]` and `base[i+1]` for which:. ```. (base[i] == 'G' & base[i+1] == 'C') | (base[i] == 'C' & base[i+1] == 'G'). ```

sentence: Quality filtering; @sfchen . Hello, can you tell me how I can do this? ```. Reads with more than 5 bases with quality scores below 15 (PHRED-scale) were discarded. ```. I find it hard to find the right parameter. Can I set the number of bases instead of the percent of the unqualified bases? Due to the fact that I have trimmed them. The do not have the same length, in order to calculate the percentage.

sentence: Not detecting the adapter in miRNAseq; It looks like FASTP is not able to detect *automatically* the adapter at all for miRNA-seq data. For example, FASTP is not able to detect *automatically* the adapter in the SE FASTQ file from https://trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Traces/sra/?run=SRR5087522. FASTP v0.19.6 was run as `fastp -i SRR5087522.fq -o test.fq`. The first 3 input reads look like this:. ```. @SRR5087522.1. TGTAACAGCAACTCCATGTGGAATGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGAACTCCA. +. CCCFFFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJIJJ. @SRR5087522.2. NAGCTTATCAGACTGATGTTGACTGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGGAACTCC. +. #4BDFFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJJJJJIJJJJIJIJCBHIJJJJJJJJJJJJ. @SRR5087522.3. NCCCGGCGGCTGGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGGAACTCCAGTCACCGTACG. +. #1=DDFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJIIJFGHHIJJIEHHHACDFFFFFEDADDD. ```. FASTQC shows that this fastq file contains most likely the *Illumina SmallRNA adapter 3'*, which according to FASTQC's database of adapters https://github.com/csf-ngs/fastqc/blob/master/Contaminants/contaminant_list.txt is this ATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. According to Illumina official document: . https://support.illumina.com/content/dam/illumina-support/documents/documentation/chemistry_documentation/experiment-design/illumina-adapter-sequences-1000000002694-09.pdf. these are all the Illumina small RNA adapters:. ```. >Illumina Small RNA v1.5 3p Adapter. ATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. >Illumina RNA 3p Adapter (RA3). TGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGG. >Illumina RNA 5p Adapter (RA5). GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 5p RNA Adapter. GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 3p RNA Adapter. TCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTGT. ```.
author: OpenGene

According to Illumina official document: . https://support.illumina.com/content/dam/illumina-support/documents/documentation/chemistry_documentation/experiment-design/illumina-adapter-sequences-1000000002694-09.pdf. these are all the Illumina small RNA adapters:. ```. >Illumina Small RNA v1.5 3p Adapter. ATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. >Illumina RNA 3p Adapter (RA3). TGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGG. >Illumina RNA 5p Adapter (RA5). GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 5p RNA Adapter. GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 3p RNA Adapter. TCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTGT. ```.

GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 3p RNA Adapter. TCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTGT. ```.

sentence: Not detecting the adapter in miRNAseq; It looks like FASTP is not able to detect *automatically* the adapter at all for miRNA-seq data. For example, FASTP is not able to detect *automatically* the adapter in the SE FASTQ file from https://trace.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Traces/sra/?run=SRR5087522. FASTP v0.19.6 was run as `fastp -i SRR5087522.fq -o test.fq`. The first 3 input reads look like this:. ```. @SRR5087522.1. TGTAACAGCAACTCCATGTGGAATGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGAACTCCA. +. CCCFFFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJIJJ. @SRR5087522.2. NAGCTTATCAGACTGATGTTGACTGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGGAACTCC. +. #4BDFFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJJJJJIJJJJIJIJCBHIJJJJJJJJJJJJ. @SRR5087522.3. NCCCGGCGGCTGGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGGAACTCCAGTCACCGTACG. +. #1=DDFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJIIJFGHHIJJIEHHHACDFFFFFEDADDD. ```. FASTQC shows that this fastq file contains most likely the *Illumina SmallRNA adapter 3'*, which according to FASTQC's database of adapters https://github.com/csf-ngs/fastqc/blob/master/Contaminants/contaminant_list.txt is this ATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. According to Illumina official document: . https://support.illumina.com/content/dam/illumina-support/documents/documentation/chemistry_documentation/experiment-design/illumina-adapter-sequences-1000000002694-09.pdf. these are all the Illumina small RNA adapters:. ```. >Illumina Small RNA v1.5 3p Adapter. FASTP v0.19.6 was run as `fastp -i SRR5087522.fq -o test.fq`. The first 3 input reads look like this:. ```. @SRR5087522.1. TGTAACAGCAACTCCATGTGGAATGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGAACTCCA. +. CCCFFFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJJIJJ. @SRR5087522.2. NAGCTTATCAGACTGATGTTGACTGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGGAACTCC. +. #4BDFFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJJJJJIJJJJIJIJCBHIJJJJJJJJJJJJ. @SRR5087522.3. NCCCGGCGGCTGGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGGAACTCCAGTCACCGTACG. +. #1=DDFFFHHHHHJJJJJJJJIIJFGHHIJJIEHHHACDFFFFFEDADDD. ```. FASTQC shows that this fastq file contains most likely the *Illumina SmallRNA adapter 3'*, which according to FASTQC's database of adapters https://github.com/csf-ngs/fastqc/blob/master/Contaminants/contaminant_list.txt is this ATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. According to Illumina official document: . https://support.illumina.com/content/dam/illumina-support/documents/documentation/chemistry_documentation/experiment-design/illumina-adapter-sequences-1000000002694-09.pdf. these are all the Illumina small RNA adapters:. ```. >Illumina Small RNA v1.5 3p Adapter. ATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. >Illumina RNA 3p Adapter (RA3). TGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGG. >Illumina RNA 5p Adapter (RA5). GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 5p RNA Adapter. GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 3p RNA Adapter. TCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTGT. ```.
author: OpenGene

FASTQC shows that this fastq file contains most likely the *Illumina SmallRNA adapter 3'*, which according to FASTQC's database of adapters https://github.com/csf-ngs/fastqc/blob/master/Contaminants/contaminant_list.txt is this ATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. According to Illumina official document: . https://support.illumina.com/content/dam/illumina-support/documents/documentation/chemistry_documentation/experiment-design/illumina-adapter-sequences-1000000002694-09.pdf. these are all the Illumina small RNA adapters:. ```. >Illumina Small RNA v1.5 3p Adapter. ATCTCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTG. >Illumina RNA 3p Adapter (RA3). TGGAATTCTCGGGTGCCAAGG. >Illumina RNA 5p Adapter (RA5). GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 5p RNA Adapter. GTTCAGAGTTCTACAGTCCGACGATC. >Illumina 3p RNA Adapter. TCGTATGCCGTCTTCTGCTTGT. ```.

author: OpenGene

sentence: fastp-Can't remove the adapt sequences with indels; Hello, I used fastp tool to do the raw NGS data QC. It's a very useful and efficient tool to do the work. But I found it can not remove adapter sequences with indels, even one base insersion or deletion after reading your adaptertrimmer.cpp source code. Can you help to update adaptertrimmer module in fastp so that it can remove adapter sequences with indels (compair to reference adapter sequence) ?
author: OpenGene

sentence: cut_right not consistent; Hi,. I was trying to trim some next-seq data with very long low quality tails. . I set the minimum mean quality to 25 but in the output results I still see reads that haven't been trimmed with long stretches of ////// in the quality(score=14). --cut_window_size 4 --cut_mean_quality 25 --cut_right. Am I missing something. example:. untrimmed. @NB500968:113:HNLHTBGX7:1:11101:4491:1068 1:N:0:CGGTTA. CAGGTGTATAGTATTCAGTATATATTTTGTAAATAAAATGTTTTGTGGCTAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGAGGGGAGGGGCCCCGGGGGGGCGGCCGGGCCCGGGTGCGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGCGAGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG. +. AAAAAE//EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE6/////E//////A////A/<///////A/E<E<//EE//////<AE/E/E//EAA/AAA/E/<A//////////EEEAAEEA66. trimmed. @NB500968:113:HNLHTBGX7:1:11101:4491:1068:CAGGTG 1:N:0:CGGTTA. TATATATTTTGTAAATAAAATGTTTTGTGGCTAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGAGGGGAGGGGCCCCGGGGGGGCGGCCGGG. +. EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE6/////E//////A////A/<///////A/E<.

sentence: shouldn't poly A trimming happen after adaptor trimming?; I'm working with 3' RNA-seq with polyT priming. in the resulting reads I still get poly A tails. I think this is happening because the adaptor is trimmed after the polyA trimming. shouldn't it happen in the other order?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Blank/missing reads in FASTQ cause malformed output FASTQ; If one of the input FASTQ files has a missing/blank sequence, the output FASTQ will be malformed. I.e. if the input FASTQ has a correct entry followed by a blank entry like this:. ```. @A00545. ACGTGCTGAC. +. FFF,:,FFFF. @A00546. +. ```. where the sequence line and quality line are both blank, then the output will have a malformed entry, like so, where there is only a "+" and a quality sequence, but no read ID or genetic sequence:. ```. @A00545. ACGTGCTGAC. +. FFF,:,FFFF. +. F:FFFFFFFF. ```. The program should either throw an error if the FASTQ file has a blank entry, or skip the entry entirely in the output. (In this case, I didn't know my FASTQ file had a blank entry—it came off the sequencer like that—but Fastp ran with no errors and I only discovered the problem during downstream analysis because the output FASTQ file was not correctly formed.)
author: OpenGene

FFF,:,FFFF. @A00546. +. ```. where the sequence line and quality line are both blank, then the output will have a malformed entry, like so, where there is only a "+" and a quality sequence, but no read ID or genetic sequence:. ```. @A00545. ACGTGCTGAC. +. FFF,:,FFFF. +. F:FFFFFFFF. ```. The program should either throw an error if the FASTQ file has a blank entry, or skip the entry entirely in the output. (In this case, I didn't know my FASTQ file had a blank entry—it came off the sequencer like that—but Fastp ran with no errors and I only discovered the problem during downstream analysis because the output FASTQ file was not correctly formed.)
author: OpenGene

sentence: The result can't repeat !!!; Hello, . I used the same raw fastq data to do the QC, but I got three different clean fastq data after repeat 3 times with the same parameter by fastp. sentence: Trim poly-G ; Hi,. Poly-G might appear at any position when using NextSeq/NovaSeq, but fastp seems to only trim poly-G at the read tail. Would it be possible to perform poly-G trimming at any position? Thank you.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Option to merge overlapping PE reads?; From the main README file, you already have code to look for PE overlaps and use this for correcting mismatches & detecting adapters. Could you add an option to output only the merged reads? Right now I would only want the overlaps as output (not interested in the non-overlapping reads). This could replace the need to call a separate FASTQ pair-merging tool like ``pear`` or ``flash``,. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3933873/. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3198573/
author: OpenGene

sentence: `fastp --help` and `fastp --version` : STDOUT versus STDERR; Hi. . I've just started using `fastp` and noticed that `fastp --help` and `fastp --version` direct their output to STDERR. Could you confirm that this is the expected route for these messages, since it is more typical (eg, according to the GNU standards http://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/html_node/_002d_002dhelp.html and various implementations of argparse / optparse) for user-requested messages to be output to STDOUT. Kind regards. Russ Hyde, U Glasgow. ----. Ubuntu 18.04 using fastp via bioconda. `fastp --version`. `fastp 0.19.7`
author: OpenGene

sentence: Only keep reads that contain certain sequence and allow cutting.; I would like to keep only reads that contain `ACTCGAGCCGAGCAGGCGCGCCGATC` from position 0 till 4 (first bases are stagger sequences). Preferably the last few (e.g. 4) bases of `ACTCGAGCCGAGCAGGCGCGCCGATC` should match exactly. The next 17 bp could be considered a UMI. sentence: some minor bug found, hopefuly my modifications are valid~; thank you for providing such a excellent opensource fastq preprocessor, I have studied your code recently and found s minor some minor bugs:. 1, the adapter sequence should be the overlap part of external provided adapterseq and the fastq read seq? If so, I think my modification is reasonable, if not, I would appreciate your idea about this treating. 2, during the estimation of read number of a fastq file, the left bytes shouldn't take the first read into account, so I think the divisor records should minus 1. check it here:

author: OpenGene

sentence: Is there any way to _identify_ the adapter sequence bases, without necessarily removing them?; I'm looking for a way to mark adapter sequences, with `XT:i:` annotations, in a manner that replicates picard's MarkIlluminaAdapters, but not remove them from the output (which I believe, through quick inspection of the source code, is the default mode). Is there a mode that allows simply marking the reads? I'd like to keep as much information as possible from the sequencer in my unaligned bam, without overly concerning myself with whether or not I've passed the correct adapter strings when trimming. .

sentence: Is there any way to _identify_ the adapter sequence bases, without necessarily removing them?; I'm looking for a way to mark adapter sequences, with `XT:i:` annotations, in a manner that replicates picard's MarkIlluminaAdapters, but not remove them from the output (which I believe, through quick inspection of the source code, is the default mode). Is there a mode that allows simply marking the reads? I'd like to keep as much information as possible from the sequencer in my unaligned bam, without overly concerning myself with whether or not I've passed the correct adapter strings when trimming. .

sentence: Distinct output file for merged PE reads; Hi, . thanks for recently adding the merging feature of PE reads #139 ! Would it be possible to implement a 3rd output parameter in order to separate the merged/unmerged reads in an intuitive way like assemblers (e.g. SPAdes) ask for them? So, we could immediately end up with cleaned R1, R2 and merged read files. For example:. ``` bash. fastp -i R1.fastq.gz -I R2.fastq.gz -o R1.clean.fastq.gz -O R2.clean.fastq.gz --out_merged R12.clean.fastq.gz. ```. Maybe worth of a distinct issue but somehow related to this:. What happens with either R1 or R2 reads resulting from successful filtering procedures but lacking a related mate? Could these also be written to a distinct file, like SE reads? Trimmomatic is able to behave that way and thus, those valid reads can be fed into downstream analyses.

sentence: filtering rRNA contamination ?; Hi ! I'm wondering if you can use SILVA database to remove rRNA contamination directly from fastq files ? It can be useful when you have prepared your samples with a RNA depletion kit. I know we can map against rRNA fasta files, keep the unmapped, and continuous the analysis but I think it can be "quicker/easier" to remove the rRNA contamination since the beginning (= fastq). . SortMeRNA (https://github.com/biocore/sortmerna) is doing this but QC/trimming/etc.. is very nice with fastp and for wet scientist with few skills, it's always better to have one tool (with several options) than thousands. Thanks ! :). Bests,.

sentence: No adapter detected but ; Dear Authors,. Could you please clarify it for me? I have a pair of fastq files with adapters trimmed by NGS facility. As was expected the adapters were undetected, ...but there were 5743820 reads with adapter trimmed. `. fastp -i IF-0029V16_1.fq.gz -I IF-0029V16_2.fq.gz \. -o ~/Trim/IF-0029V16_1.fq.gz -O ~/Trim/IF-0029V16_2.fq.gz \. --html ~/Trim/IF-0029V16.html --json ~/Trim/IF-0029V16.json \. --report_title ~/Trim/IF-0029V16.txt \. --detect_adapter_for_pe \. --trim_poly_x \. --correction \. --thread 16 \. --dont_overwrite \. --length_required 36`. ```. Process IF-0029V16. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... No adapter detected for read2. ```. ```. Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 126835844. reads failed due to low quality: 1411636. reads failed due to too many N: 333694. reads failed due to too short: 34642. reads with adapter trimmed: 5743820. bases trimmed due to adapters: 64967338. reads corrected by overlap analysis: 2688890. bases corrected by overlap analysis: 3830916. Duplication rate: 9.66233%. Insert size peak (evaluated by paired-end reads): 130. ```
author: OpenGene

As was expected the adapters were undetected, ...but there were 5743820 reads with adapter trimmed. `. fastp -i IF-0029V16_1.fq.gz -I IF-0029V16_2.fq.gz \. -o ~/Trim/IF-0029V16_1.fq.gz -O ~/Trim/IF-0029V16_2.fq.gz \. --html ~/Trim/IF-0029V16.html --json ~/Trim/IF-0029V16.json \. --report_title ~/Trim/IF-0029V16.txt \. --detect_adapter_for_pe \. --trim_poly_x \. --correction \. --thread 16 \. --dont_overwrite \. --length_required 36`. ```. Process IF-0029V16. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... No adapter detected for read2. ```. ```. Filtering result:. reads passed filter: 126835844. reads failed due to low quality: 1411636. reads failed due to too many N: 333694. reads failed due to too short: 34642. reads with adapter trimmed: 5743820. bases trimmed due to adapters: 64967338. reads corrected by overlap analysis: 2688890. bases corrected by overlap analysis: 3830916. Duplication rate: 9.66233%. Insert size peak (evaluated by paired-end reads): 130. ```

author: OpenGene

sentence: Default options not working; I'm trimming some data from ENA with fastp. Here is the dataset https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/data/view/SRR5525985. and the command line I'm using. `fastp -i SRR5525985_1.fastq.gz -I SRR5525985_2.fastq.gz -o SRR5525985_1.tr.fastq.gz -O SRR5525985_2.tr.fastq.gz`. fastp version 0.20.0. However, the output is not as expected. The trimmed reads still have a similar dropoff in quality as the untrimmed reads. . The fastp.html file produced is [here](https://www.dropbox.com/s/qm4a72urrees3ov/fastp.html?dl=0) (dropbox link as github doesn't allow html upload). I'm probably just reading the options incorrectly, but I expected the output to be high quality (> Q20) to the end of the read. Can you help?
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: -f, --trim_front1 option gives fewer than expected counts; Thanks for an excellent piece of software - fastp is fast, accurate, and the defaults/options/reports for merging/trimming are perfect for all our needs! However, assuming I've understood the options correctly, there is possibly a bug:. The SRA run SRR2413286 (for example) has a 20 bp adapter at the front (left) of the read that needs to be trimmed, and a 3' adapter:. I get different counts if I trim with and without the -f 20 option even if I adjust the -l --length_required limit accordingly. Code to reproduce (using fastp 0.19.4). ```. wget ftp://ftp.sra.ebi.ac.uk/vol1/fastq/SRR241/006/SRR2413286/SRR2413286.fastq.gz. fastp -i SRR2413286.fastq.gz -a GTGTCAGTCACTTCCAGCGG -f 20 -l 18 -n 0 -o SRR2413286.fastp.f20.l18.fq. fastp -i SRR2413286.fastq.gz -a GTGTCAGTCACTTCCAGCGG -l 38 -n 0 -o SRR2413286.fastp.l38.fq. wc -l SRR2413286.fastp*fq. 25822936 SRR2413286.fastp.f20.l18.fq. 26231448 SRR2413286.fastp.l38.fq. ```. Is fastp doing something else that is causing the number of reads in the `-f 20 -l 18` case to be lower than the second case `-l 38` ?
author: OpenGene

sentence: -f, --trim_front1 option gives fewer than expected counts; Thanks for an excellent piece of software - fastp is fast, accurate, and the defaults/options/reports for merging/trimming are perfect for all our needs! The SRA run SRR2413286 (for example) has a 20 bp adapter at the front (left) of the read that needs to be trimmed, and a 3' adapter:. I get different counts if I trim with and without the -f 20 option even if I adjust the -l --length_required limit accordingly. Code to reproduce (using fastp 0.19.4). ```. wget ftp://ftp.sra.ebi.ac.uk/vol1/fastq/SRR241/006/SRR2413286/SRR2413286.fastq.gz. fastp -i SRR2413286.fastq.gz -a GTGTCAGTCACTTCCAGCGG -f 20 -l 18 -n 0 -o SRR2413286.fastp.f20.l18.fq. fastp -i SRR2413286.fastq.gz -a GTGTCAGTCACTTCCAGCGG -l 38 -n 0 -o SRR2413286.fastp.l38.fq. wc -l SRR2413286.fastp*fq. 25822936 SRR2413286.fastp.f20.l18.fq. 26231448 SRR2413286.fastp.l38.fq. ```. Is fastp doing something else that is causing the number of reads in the `-f 20 -l 18` case to be lower than the second case `-l 38` ?

sentence: Makefile enhancements; The patch below adds DESTDIR support and an install-strip target. This will facilitate installing fastp via package managers, most of which can use these features by default. Also suggesting a slightly cleaner way to amend CXXFLAGS, but it works for me either way. It was pretty easy already, though - thanks for making fastp simple and portable to begin with! ```. --- Makefile.orig	2019-04-17 03:23:22 UTC. +++ Makefile. @@ -3,9 +3,11 @@ DIR_SRC := ./src. DIR_OBJ := ./obj. . PREFIX ?= /usr/local. +DESTDIR ?=. BINDIR ?= $(PREFIX)/bin. INCLUDE_DIRS ?=. LIBRARY_DIRS ?=. +STRIP_CMD ?= strip. . SRC := $(wildcard ${DIR_SRC}/*.cpp). OBJ := $(patsubst %.cpp,${DIR_OBJ}/%.o,$(notdir ${SRC})). @@ -15,7 +17,8 @@ TARGET := fastp. BIN_TARGET := ${TARGET}. . CXX ?= g++. -CXXFLAGS := -std=c++11 -g -O3 -I${DIR_INC} $(foreach includedir,$(INCLUDE_DIRS),-I$(includedir)) ${CXXFLAGS}. +CXXFLAGS ?= -g -O3. +CXXFLAGS += -std=c++11 -I${DIR_INC} $(foreach includedir,$(INCLUDE_DIRS),-I$(includedir)). LIBS := -lz -lpthread. LD_FLAGS := $(foreach librarydir,$(LIBRARY_DIRS),-L$(librarydir)) $(LIBS) $(LD_FLAGS). . @@ -38,5 +41,8 @@ make_obj_dir:. 	fi. . install:. -	install $(TARGET) $(BINDIR)/$(TARGET). +	install $(TARGET) $(DESTDIR)$(BINDIR)/$(TARGET). 	@echo "Installed.". +. +install-strip: install. +	$(STRIP_CMD) $(DESTDIR)$(BINDIR)/$(TARGET). ```
author: OpenGene

LD_FLAGS := $(foreach librarydir,$(LIBRARY_DIRS),-L$(librarydir)) $(LIBS) $(LD_FLAGS). . @@ -38,5 +41,8 @@ make_obj_dir:. 	fi. . install:. -	install $(TARGET) $(BINDIR)/$(TARGET). +	install $(TARGET) $(DESTDIR)$(BINDIR)/$(TARGET). 	@echo "Installed.". +. +install-strip: install. +	$(STRIP_CMD) $(DESTDIR)$(BINDIR)/$(TARGET). ```

author: OpenGene

sentence: how does fastp deal withoverlapped bases with high quality both on read1 and read2; HI, The readme says the rule of PE correction is to correct the base if the overlapped base on one of the read is of high quality while the other one is of ultra low quality. However, I have encountered some tricky conditions in ctDNA in which most of the read pairs are highly overlapped since ctDNA fragments are usually shorter than 300bp: the base on read1 and read2 are both of high base quality, so how does fastp deal with overlapped bases with high quality both on read1 and read2?
author: OpenGene

author: OpenGene

sentence: is trimming for PE symmetrical; Thank you very much or developing fastp -- it is fast and does all that is needed. Small question. Would it be possible to clarify whether adapter trimming is symmetrical for PE reads? For example if an adapter is detected for read 1 but not for read 2, will read 2 be trimmed anyway based on the adapter position in read 1. Seems that tools such as Atropos follow such rule. Thank you. Dieter.

author: OpenGene

sentence: Is the PHRED algorithm used when trimming or averaging quality scores?; I wonder if "naive trimming" or the PHRED algorithm is used by `fastp`:. From: http://seqanswers.com/forums/showpost.php?p=144154&postcount=17. ```. Imagine a read with this quality profile:. 40, 40, 40, 40, 2, 2, 2, 2, 40, 2. What I would term "naive trimming" to Q10 would trim only the last base with quality 2, and stop because the next base has Q40. This would leave 4 internal bases with Q2, which is not desirable. The Phred algorithm would trim the last 6 bases, because their average quality (calculated by summing the error probabilities) is 2.79, which is below 10. Trimming regions with average quality below a threshold gives the optimal result in terms of the ratio of retained bases to the expected number of errors. ```. I ran the adaptor trimming comparison described in http://seqanswers.com/forums/showpost.php?p=138702&postcount=2 and found out that `fastp` removes adaptors better that `bbduk.sh` (98% vs 96%, at least on that type of comparison) and would like to eventually use `fastp` in my pipeline but I am curious about how the quality scores are treated for trimming. Thanks. Edgardo. Edit: I realized this question is related to this post: https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/issues/110 I agree, quality filtering should be based on the probability of error not just on the raw quality score (or at least allow the user switch to that mode of filtering).

I ran the adaptor trimming comparison described in http://seqanswers.com/forums/showpost.php?p=138702&postcount=2 and found out that `fastp` removes adaptors better that `bbduk.sh` (98% vs 96%, at least on that type of comparison) and would like to eventually use `fastp` in my pipeline but I am curious about how the quality scores are treated for trimming. Thanks. Edgardo. Edit: I realized this question is related to this post: https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp/issues/110 I agree, quality filtering should be based on the probability of error not just on the raw quality score (or at least allow the user switch to that mode of filtering).

author: OpenGene

sentence: Incorrect adapter detected?; Sometimes `fastp` detects what could be real genomic repetitive sequence as adaptor, for example:. ```. Detected read1 adapter: | AACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACC. ```. Has anyone else seen this behaviour? My command was:. ```. fastp -w 16 --dont_overwrite -Q -z 1 --in1 SB12_R1.fq.gz --in2 SB12_R2.fq.gz --out1 ../01_adapters_removed/tmp_fastp/SB12_R1.fq.gz --out2 ../01_adapters_removed/tmp_fastp/SB12_R2.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -l 21 --json ../01_adapters_removed/SB12.fastp.adapters.json --html ../01_adapters_removed/SB12.fastp.adapters.html. ```. Searching the literature, `AAACCCT` seems to be a common motif in telomeric repeats in plants:. https://www.nature.com/articles/nature15714/tables/1. How can I avoid this false detection? Edgardo
author: OpenGene

sentence: Incorrect adapter detected?; Sometimes `fastp` detects what could be real genomic repetitive sequence as adaptor, for example:. ```. Detected read1 adapter: | AACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACC. ```. Has anyone else seen this behaviour? My command was:. ```. fastp -w 16 --dont_overwrite -Q -z 1 --in1 SB12_R1.fq.gz --in2 SB12_R2.fq.gz --out1 ../01_adapters_removed/tmp_fastp/SB12_R1.fq.gz --out2 ../01_adapters_removed/tmp_fastp/SB12_R2.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -l 21 --json ../01_adapters_removed/SB12.fastp.adapters.json --html ../01_adapters_removed/SB12.fastp.adapters.html. ```. Searching the literature, `AAACCCT` seems to be a common motif in telomeric repeats in plants:. https://www.nature.com/articles/nature15714/tables/1. How can I avoid this false detection? Edgardo
author: OpenGene

Detected read1 adapter: | AACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACCCTAAACC. ```. Has anyone else seen this behaviour? My command was:. ```. fastp -w 16 --dont_overwrite -Q -z 1 --in1 SB12_R1.fq.gz --in2 SB12_R2.fq.gz --out1 ../01_adapters_removed/tmp_fastp/SB12_R1.fq.gz --out2 ../01_adapters_removed/tmp_fastp/SB12_R2.fq.gz --detect_adapter_for_pe -l 21 --json ../01_adapters_removed/SB12.fastp.adapters.json --html ../01_adapters_removed/SB12.fastp.adapters.html. ```. Searching the literature, `AAACCCT` seems to be a common motif in telomeric repeats in plants:. https://www.nature.com/articles/nature15714/tables/1. How can I avoid this false detection? Edgardo

sentence: Incorporating a UBAM to FastQ step to the fastp package; Some of our Sequencing Service providers deliver to us paired-end sequence data in UBAM (unaligned) file format containing both forward and reverse reads. Do you think it would be helpful to many users if you included a step that converts the UBAM file to FastQ to the fastp tool? I am new to using Biostars otherwise I would have posted this comment there to find out what other people think about this. Thank you.

sentence: Sum of read numbers of sub files is not equal to the input files; I'm using `fastp` to split the input (1M PE reads) into 20 sub files. But in the outputted files, there were only 977838. What's the reason? Is it possible to keep all the reads in the sub files? Thanks.

sentence: Just fastqc; Can fastp just do fastqc and not do filtering and trimming?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Is it possible to only produce the report, without output fastq files.; Hello, . I was wondering if it is possible to use fastp in some cases as a much faster FastQC. I see that I can turn off adapter trimming and quality trimming (-A, -Q), and thus fastp won't trim my inputs and only output report. Is it possible for fastp to do this without outputting the fastqs afterwards?

sentence: Feature request: filter duplicates; fastp currently already evaluates and reports duplicated reads. Based on my reading of the source code and the documentation, fastp doesn't currently filter out duplicate reads. It would be nice to have an option that enables this type of filtering.

sentence: Zero number of reads in some of the files; Hi there,. Fastp is great! . One thing I encounter is that some of the files doesn't have any reads if I use `--split`. Here is the command I used. . ```. fastp -i A_1.fq -I A_2.fq --split 80 -o 1.fastq.gz -O 2.fastq.gz --disable_quality_filtering --disable_adapter_trimming --disable_trim_poly_g. ```. Is it possible to give at least some reads? I'd like to integrate fastp in a pipeline but the empty file will cause some errors. Thanks. .
author: OpenGene

sentence: threading does not obey limits; I have been running with the default threads and explicitly setting `--thread 2` and in both cases, I see about 250-400% cpu usage. For parallelization that is an issue, as it appears the workers have access to more than one thread each.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Include a flag to set seed; It would be great to be able to set a random seed when invoking `fastp`. We'd like to achieve determinism so that we can use fastp in a reproducible pipeline.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Include a flag to set seed; It would be great to be able to set a random seed when invoking `fastp`. We'd like to achieve determinism so that we can use fastp in a reproducible pipeline.
author: OpenGene

sentence: rRNA or mtRNA sequences are detected as adapter sequences?; Hi, developer. I used fastp with some RNA-seq data, and found the detected adapter sequences are identical to some rRNA or mtRNA sequences. . For example:. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... GTTCGATTCCTTCCTTTCTTATTTTACTTTTACATAGGTTGGTTCCTCGAATGTGTGATA. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... CAAACTCATGCATATCACATAGTTAATCCAAGTCCATGACCATTAACTGGAGCCTTTTCA. When I run blast with these sequences, it says these sequences are 100% identical to mouse mtRNA. . It's that means the RNA-seq sample contain a lot of rRNA and mtRNA? Should I trim these sequences before mapping?
author: OpenGene

sentence: Quality trimming DOES not work!; I used fastp version 0.19.7 with the following command line. fastp -i input1 -o output1 -I input2 -O output2 -q 20 --length_required 50 -w 4. I checked my output and found many dots (phred score 13) in the last line of each entry. Also, I compared the results from the solexqa and the results are significantly different. Did I use the correct commandline for quality trimming? or is it something wrong with fastp? Thanks.

sentence: get PE and SE reads from uneven two fastq files [feature request]; Hello, Fastp team members! https://github.com/jvivian/fastq_pair. https://github.com/linsalrob/fastq-pair. https://github.com/lh3/seqtk/issues/82. If we have two files, R1.fa, R2.fa. R1.fa. ```. >a/1. AT. >b/1. AC. >d/1. AG. ```. R2.fa. ```. >a/2. AA. >d/2. CC. >e/2. TT. ```. then, using fastp, we get:. paried.R1.fa. ```. >a/1. AT. >d/1. AG. ```. paried.R2.fa. ```. >a/2. AA. >d/2. CC. ```. single.fa. ```. >b/1. AC. >e/2. TT. ```.
author: OpenGene

sentence: Adapter tirmming ; Hi, . I have the special sequence **GTGCTCGATAGACAT** in my reads, and I just want to trim the special 15bps not trimming other bases. Using the command I described blow, I found the special bases all still in the output file. We know that there are several categories in Cutadapter ,such as anchored or unanchored. I want to know fastp how to trim the adapter(the special bases)? Why there are still adapter in the outfile ? Even I used the _--adapter_sequence_ parameter , I found fastp trimmed all bases after the adapter sequence, how to trim some special bases ? Let us ignore other factors, such as base quality. ```. $ grep GTGCTCGATAGACAT test1 test2 testout1 testout2. #original reads. test1:NACCTTAGATGAGGGTGCTCGATAGACATACCCTGAGAAGCCAGGCACCCCAGGTGAAGGGATGCTTAGCTCTGACTTAGACAGGATTTCCACAGAAGGTGAGGCTGTGACCCGTACCTCTTTGTGTATAAGGGTTTTCTATGGGAGAAG. test1:NTCACGGGCCATCGGTGCTCGATAGACATCATCCTTCATCAAAAAGCCATTTGACCGTGGAGAAGTAGAATCAATGGAAGATGATACTAATGGAAATCTAATGGAGGTGGAGGATCAGTCATCCAATGTCTATCGAGCACAGATCGGAAG. test1:NGGCGACGCCGGTAGTGCTCGATAGACATCCATCTATGCAGATATTCAAGAGTCAGCCATGCTACATCTATTAGTTGACTGGATGCACTGAAATAGAAAATGCAGACAAGATTGCTTCTATTTCCAGAATTCTTTTACATTTGGTGTGCC. test1:NTGGTAATCCGATAGTGCTCGATAGACATCGTGTTACATATGTGAAAAAAAGGAGAACCAAGCTATATCTGAACAAAAATTCCGTGGTTTTATATTTGAGTCTATCGAGTGTGTGCATATGTGTATGTTGAGTGTATACATTAGTATATA. test1:NCTGGGTCGTTGTTGTGCTCGATAGACATCTTCGGAGCTGTTGGGTACACTTCCGAGACGGGGCAGCCTGGCAGAGGCGCTTCTCACTTCCCAGACAGGGCGGCCGGGCAGAGGAGCTCCTCACTTCCCAGATGGGGCGGCCGGGCAGAG. test2:GTGCTCGATAGACATCAGAGAAGCTGTACAGATCACAGTCCCAAAGATAGGACCTCCTCCTTCTCCCATAGAAAACCCTTATACACAAAGAGGTACGGGTCACAGCCTCACCTACTGTGGCAATCAGTGCTAAGTCAGAGCTAAGCATCC. test2:GTGCTCGATAGACATTGGATGACTGATCCTCCACCTCCATTAGATTTCCATTAGTATCATCTTCCATTGATTCTACTTCTCCACGGTCAAATGGCTTTGTGAGGAAGGATGATGTCTATCGAGCACCGATGGCCCGTGAGAGATCGGAAG. test2:GTGCTCGATAGACATATGAATAATGCATCTGTTATAATTCTGCTTTCCAAAGTACGTTTTCTGGGCACACCAAATGTAAAAGAATTCTGGAAATAGAAGCAATCTTGTCTGCATTTTCTATTTCAGTGCATCCAGTCAACTAATAGATTT. test2:GTGCTCGATAGACATA

sentence: undefined option: --detect_adapter_for_pe; Hi,. I've used this code in the past without issue, but now, the --detect_adapter_for_pe is throwing an error. Here is the code chunk:. activate_conda_environment ${PROJECT} fastp. fastp -i ${DATA_RAW}/${sample}_R1_*.fastq.gz \. -I ${DATA_RAW}/${sample}_R2_*.fastq.gz \. -o ${DATA_FILT}/${sample}.R1.filt.fastq.gz \. -O ${DATA_FILT}/${sample}.R2.filt.fastq.gz \. -h ${FASTP_REPORTS_DIR}/${sample}.fastp.report.html \. -j ${FASTP_REPORTS_DIR}/${sample}.fastp.report.json \. -w ${N_THREADS} \. --detect_adapter_for_pe \. --correction \. --cut_by_quality3 \. --cut_window_size 5 \. --cut_mean_quality 30 \. --overrepresentation_analysis || { echo "fastp failed" ; exit 1; }. source deactivate. Here is the error message:. undefined option: --detect_adapter_for_pe. Thanks

Here is the code chunk:. activate_conda_environment ${PROJECT} fastp. fastp -i ${DATA_RAW}/${sample}_R1_*.fastq.gz \. -I ${DATA_RAW}/${sample}_R2_*.fastq.gz \. -o ${DATA_FILT}/${sample}.R1.filt.fastq.gz \. -O ${DATA_FILT}/${sample}.R2.filt.fastq.gz \. -h ${FASTP_REPORTS_DIR}/${sample}.fastp.report.html \. -j ${FASTP_REPORTS_DIR}/${sample}.fastp.report.json \. -w ${N_THREADS} \. --detect_adapter_for_pe \. --correction \. --cut_by_quality3 \. --cut_window_size 5 \. --cut_mean_quality 30 \. --overrepresentation_analysis || { echo "fastp failed" ; exit 1; }. source deactivate. Here is the error message:. undefined option: --detect_adapter_for_pe. Thanks

author: OpenGene

sentence: polyA trimming; Hi there,. Thank you for developing fastp. I try to run it on a 3'seq experiment (without any option for polyA trimming), and fastp i) does not detect any adapters, ii) does not trim any reads. And in practice, I know that I do have many reads spanning the polyA tail and then the adapter sequence, as this one. `CCCAACGAAACTAGACGAGCTAACTAAGAATAGCTAAAAGAGCACACCCGTCTATGTAGCAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGATCGGAAGAGCAACCGTCTGAA. `. So, is there any parameter to add, so that it can detect such case ? Thanks. Here is the command line I used :. `. fastp --qualified_quality_phred 0 --disable_trim_poly_g --length_required 10 -i input.fastq.gz -o input_trimmed.fastq.gz -j input.fastp.json -h input.fastp.html --thread 2. `. Nicolas

sentence: GZIP:invalid compressed data--format violated; Hi there,. I found the output of fastp was something wrong. `gzip: xxx.clean.2.fq.gz: invalid compressed data--format violated` when I used `zcat xxx.clean.2.fq.gz`; . But there was no any error log during the fastp running time, So I wonder if the fastp can provide some check if the output Is really what it supposed to output. Thanks!

sentence: compression issue; Using compressed fastq files, I tried to run other programs for alignment, etc., but . got this message -- decompression OK, trail ing garbage ignored. Then, I tried to simply decompress the fastqs using gunzip to see what's going on, but then this message was thrown instead --invalid compressed data--format violated. Do you have any clue on these issues? Many thanks,. Segun .

sentence: compression issue; Using compressed fastq files, I tried to run other programs for alignment, etc., but . got this message -- decompression OK, trail ing garbage ignored. Then, I tried to simply decompress the fastqs using gunzip to see what's going on, but then this message was thrown instead --invalid compressed data--format violated. Do you have any clue on these issues? Many thanks,. Segun .

author: OpenGene

sentence: More memory need and running slowly for Hisex xTen data; It seems that fastp need a lot of memory for Hisex xTen data. Maybe as big as the fastq file. And it's running slowly when there is not enough memory. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17471583/62686588-9dfa5480-b9f7-11e9-9a7f-0ee3c7ab83ca.png).

sentence: No reads detected at all.; Good afternoon,. I've been using `fastp` successfully without issue for several months now, but suddenly the program will not process/recognize any reads at all. I have attempted this with both gzipped and uncompressed fastq files with the same results. I even tested this on fastq files that were successfully trimmed with fastp several months ago and it fails. . I've ran this for >200 samples, gzipped and not, and the result is the same each time, a completely empty output file. . Here's the output of a single file:. ```. sentence: No reads detected at all.; Good afternoon,. I've been using `fastp` successfully without issue for several months now, but suddenly the program will not process/recognize any reads at all. I have attempted this with both gzipped and uncompressed fastq files with the same results. I even tested this on fastq files that were successfully trimmed with fastp several months ago and it fails. . File format from `head -4 filename`. ```. @HISEQ:349:C9CG2ANXX:2:1101:1389:1976 1:N:0:TCCTAT. TTCCCTTTCTTCCAGTGAAATGACCCGACAACAATTGAAATAGATTATTTCATGGTGCATATGCGGGAGTAATGAACGATATAAATATTAAACCAGTGTATGCTCCCAGCTGGC. +. sentence: No reads detected at all.; Good afternoon,. I've been using `fastp` successfully without issue for several months now, but suddenly the program will not process/recognize any reads at all. I have attempted this with both gzipped and uncompressed fastq files with the same results. I even tested this on fastq files that were successfully trimmed with fastp several months ago and it fails. . File format from `head -4 filename`. ```. @HISEQ:349:C9CG2ANXX:2:1101:1389:1976 1:N:0:TCCTAT. TTCCCTTTCTTCCAGTGAAATGACCCGACAACAATTGAAATAGATTATTTCATGGTGCATATGCGGGAGTAATGAACGATATAAATATTAAACCAGTGTATGCTCCCAGCTGGC. +. FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFBFBFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF<FFFFFBFFFFFFFF<BFFFBFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFBFFFFFFFFFF<FFFFBFFFFFFFFFFB. ```. fastp `version 0.20.0` command:. ```bash. fastp --in1 $1.F.fq.gz --in2 $1.R.fq.gz --out1 $1.R1.fq.gz --out2 $1.R2.fq.gz --cut_front --cut_tail --cut_window_size 5 --cut_mean_quality 15 --correction -q 15 -u 50 -j $1.json -h $1.html --detect_adapter_for_pe &> $1.trim.log. ```. I've ran this for >200 samples, gzipped and not, and the result is the same each time, a completely empty output file. . Here's the output of a single file:. ```. ERROR: sequence and quality have different length:. @HISEQ:349:C9CG2ANXX:2:1101:1389:1976 2:N:0:TCCTAT. CTTTGATTCAGCCAGCTGGGAGCATACACTGGTTTAATATTTATATCGTTCATTACTCCCGCATATGCACCATGAAATAATCTATTTCAATTGTTGTCGGGTCATTTCACTGGA. +. BFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFBBFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFB<FFFFB. Detecting adapter sequence for read1... No adapter detected for read1. Detecting adapter sequence for read2... ERROR: sequence and quality have different length:. @HISEQ:349:C9CG2ANXX:2:1101:1389:1976 2:N:0:TCCTAT. CTTTGATTCAGCCAGCTGGGAGCATACACTGGTTTAATATTTATATCGTTCATTACTCCCGCATATGCACCATGAAATAATCTATTTCAATTGTTGTCGGGTCATTTCACTGGA. +. BFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFBBFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFB<FFFFB. No adapter detected for read2
